qas.question: After what treaty did Savoia gain control of Italy?
For what event did Charles III choose Sicily as the location?
Where did the Royal Court reside?
Where did the capital city move in 1817?
Whose son died on the way to Palermo and is buried there?
What treaty caused the Savoy to loose Sicily?
Where was Charles the II crowned King of Sicily?
Who took refuge in Palermo in the 17th century?
What became the capital of the Two Sicilies after Naples?

context: After the <a0_0><b5_0>Treaty of Utrecht<b5_0/> (1713)<a0_0/>, Sicily was handed over to the Savoia, but by 1734 it was again a Bourbon possession. <a4_0>Charles III<a4_0/> chose <b6_0>Palermo<b6_0/> for <a1_0>his coronation<a1_0/> as King of Sicily. Charles had new houses built for the growing population, while trade and industry grew as well. However, by now Palermo was now just another provincial city as the <b7_0>Royal Court<b7_0/> resided in Naples. Charles' son <b8_0>Ferdinand<b8_0/>, though disliked by the population, took refuge in Palermo after the French Revolution in 1798. His son Alberto died on the way to Palermo and is buried in the city. When the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies was founded, the original capital city was <b9_0>Palermo<b9_0/> (1816) but a year later moved to <a2_0><a3_0>Naples<a3_0/><a2_0/>.
